Content: @Cryptoon   Small/medium size commercial operation .   The idea if if everything works out legally is to have a B2B barter exchange where mined coin can act as a clearing mechanism for outstanding credit.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: 90% of my kWh is going to equihash.   Though have been bouncing back and forth on picking up a bunch of sha asics just to get power bill higher ( a lot better rate) .    I just have a feeling though there is going to be a 25-35 TH for ~1500w soon, given by bitmain prices and network hashrate.  Haven't pulled the trigger on it.  @ComputerGenie   Do you find it worthwhile to mine with the sha ASICs?

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: @polycryptoblog thanks for the clarification, and how does this work exactly? People start mining or rent hashing power and use the hashing power as colleteral to start paying off debt?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Barter exchanges have a perennial issue of having too much credit floating in the network at any given time.  This is due to two factors,  1) lack of double coincidence of wants 2) overwhelming amount of soft good vendors ( services ) compared to amount of hard good vendors.  (Products/things).  The 2nd exacerbates the first.   Mining will provide a hard good into the barter exchange economy ,  and the icing on top is that hard Good is comparatively liquid.  Eventually the farm will resell miners, lease hosting as well.  FinCEN also has given the green light on selling mined coins as not being money transmission.   The overarching idea with the barter exchange is to create a credit network in the Komodo ecosystem giving it a stablecoin.  The big holdup is B2C interaction,  my original idea was to use something like the burn protocol to issue trade credit vouchers but I have some concerns with that as I stated in KBS channel.

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Cool! Will def keep following future developments
